result.markdown:
--- title: "Week 3: Data Visualization" subtitle: "`{ggplot2}`" author: "Joe Nese" institute: "University of Oregon
Fall 2024" format: revealjs: theme: default highlight-style: github incremental: false fig-width: 9 fig-height: 3.5 scrollable: true multiplex: true execute: echo: true warning: false cache: true --- ## Housekeeping * Homework 1 due today * Groups due today - I need emails from everyone by 5pm (if you have not already emailed) # Homework 1 # Data Visualization with {ggplot2} Week 3 ## Agenda {.smaller} `{ggplot2}` * syntax * continuous data visualizations * categorical data visualizations * options + color/fill + transparency + labels + facets **Learning Objectives** * Understand the basic syntax requirements for `{ggplot2}` * Recognize various options for displaying continuous and categorical data * Familiarity with various `{ggplot2}` options + color/fill + transparency + labels + facets # Share! ## [`{datapasta}`](https://github.com/MilesMcBain/datapasta) * Copy and paste data to and from `R` * VERY handy! * Good for [reprex](https://github.com/tidyverse/reprex) + posting questions on [Posit Community](https://forum.posit.co/) or stackoverflow [**demo**]{style="color:#D55E00;"} ## ![](https://cdn.myportfolio.com/45214904-6a61-4e23-98d6-b140f8654a40/b467ee99-87e3-4663-ae27-aaf027f940ce_rw_1920.png?h=0573cb8b960ba2f2c8486188761f03e0){width="70%"} ::: aside Credit [Allison Horst](https://allisonhorst.com/data-science-art) ::: ## Providing grammar for: {.smaller} * Graphics + `{ggplot2}` * Data manipulations + `{dplyr}` + `{tidyr}` * Expanding area of specialized topics + `{lubridate}` + `{glue}` + `{tidymodels}` * Many more... ## Providing grammar for: {.smaller} * Graphics + `{ggplot2}` * Data manipulations + `{dplyr}` + `{tidyr}` * Expanding area of specialized topics + `{lubridate}` + `{glue}` + `{tidymodels}` * Many more... # {ggplot2} ## The `{ggplot2}` package `gg` stands for the "grammar of graphics" :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://ggplot2-book.org/cover.jpg){width="50%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://images-us.bookshop.org/ingram/9780387245447.jpg?height=500&v=v2) ::: :::: ## Resources The `{ggplot2}` package is one of the most popular `R` packages, and there are many resources to learn the syntax * ggplot2 book (email me for digital copy) * Posit [cheat sheet](https://rstudio.github.io/cheatsheets/html/data-visualization.html?_gl=1*1j49xha*_ga*MTM2MTAwMDI2MS4xNjk2OTY0NDAy*_ga_2C0WZ1JHG0*MTY5Njk2NDQwMi4xLjAuMTY5Njk2NDQwMi4wLjAuMA..) + Can be helpful, perhaps more so after a little experience * [R Graphics Cookbook](http://www.cookbook-r.com/Graphs/) * [R Graph Gallery](https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/index.html) + past students have really liked this one ## Components {.smaller} Every `ggplot` plot has three components 1. **data** + the `data` used to produce the plot 2. **aesthetic mappings (`aes`)** + between variables and visual properties 3. **layer(s)** + usually through the `geom_*()` function to produce geometric shapes to be rendered . . . **`ggplot()` always takes a data frame (tibble) as the first argument** ## Basic syntax {.smaller} [ggplot(]{style="color:#D55E00"}[data]{style="color:#0072B2"}, [aes(]{style="color:#009E73"}x = xvar, y = yvar[)]{style="color:#009E73"}[)]{style="color:#D55E00"} [+]{style="color:#CC79A7"}
[geom_function()]{style="color:#E69f00"} . . . [ggplot()]{style="color:#D55E00"} = the function is `ggplot` and the package is `{ggplot2}` . . . [data]{style="color:#0072B2"} = the data to be plotted . . . [aes(]{style="color:#009E73"}x = xvar, y = yvar[)]{style="color:#009E73"} = the `aes`thetic mappings . . . [geom_function()]{style="color:#E69f00"} = the `geom`etrics of the plot; the "[function()]{style="color:#E69f00"}" here represents any of the `geom_*` offerings . . . ::: {.fragment} note the [+]{style="color:#CC79A7"} and NOT the `%>%` ::: ## `{ggplot2}` template ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data, aes(mappings)) + geom_function() ``` ::: . . . or equivalently . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data %>% ggplot(aes(mappings)) + geom_function() ``` ::: ## Some data for today ![](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/figures/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="10%"} [run the following]{style="color:#D55E00;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(palmerpenguins) head(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 8 species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 # ℹ 2 more variables: sex , year ``` ::: ::: # Continuous Data ## Setting up a plot Run the following code. What do you see? ::: {.cell output-location='slide'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/pengemp-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Setting up a plot We have to add some layers! ![](./images/owl.PNG) ## Setting up a plot It's ready for you to add some `geom`etric layers...what should we add? ## How about points? ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Adding layers * In the previous slide, we added a layer of points * The `geom_point()` layer is a function, complete with it's own arguments . . . Let’s change the color of the points How would you change the color of the points? or How would you find out about changing the color of the points? . . . `?geom_point` ## `color` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "magenta") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/peng-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Add another layer Let's add a smoothed line with `geom_smooth()` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "magenta") + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Add another layer Let's add a smoothed line with `geom_smooth()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "magenta") + geom_smooth() ``` ::: *Note*: This is **NOT** the same as `geom_line()`. We are fitting a line of best fit with `geom_smooth()` ## You try You probably got the [message]{style="color:#CC79A7;"} below when you ran (defaults) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "magenta") + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/peng-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: . . . Change the `method` to `"lm"` ## Let's do this one together Look at the help page – `?geom_smooth` 1. Remove the `confidence` interval around the line 2. Now change the `*SE*` band to reflect a 68% confidence interval ## `color`: global vs. conditional Prior examples changed colors globally - `geom_point(color = "magenta")` . . . Use `aes()` to access variables, and color according to a specific variable . . . - We use variable names within `aes()` . . . Let’s check the data again (`head()`) and the "species" variable (`table()`) . . . [let's do this together]{style="color:#D55E00;"} ## ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/peng-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## `color`: global vs. conditional ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) ``` ::: * When we did `geom_point(color = "magenta")` we put quotes around the color * Why now is "species" not in quotes? . . . * color names/hex codes are in quotes **NOT** in the `aes()` * variable names are in the `aes()` **NOT** in quotes * `aes()` is where you map to your data! ## Conditional flow through layers {.smaller} If we use something like `color = “x”` in the first `aes`thetic, it will carry on through all additional layers These two codes are the same: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% gplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() ``` ::: . . . But these two are not...why? [run to find out]{style="color:#D55E00;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) + geom_smooth() ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() ``` ::: ## Be mindful with `aes()` Using `aes()` when you **don't** need it What is happening here? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(color = "blue")) + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Be mindful with `aes()` **Not** using `aes()` when you need it What is happening here? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = species) + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'species' not found ``` ::: ::: ::: aside Kind of helpful message here. ::: # Themes ## Let's talk themes * The default is `theme_gray()` + I don't like it * But there are a lot of build-in alternative in `{ggplot2}` + `theme_minimal()` is my favorite * Check out the [`{ggthemes}`](https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/) package for a lot of alternatives + These days I often use the [`colorblind`](https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/colorblind/) theme for discrete values in my plots + I also like the [`{MetBrewer}`](https://github.com/BlakeRMills/MetBrewer) package, inspired by art in the Met * Check out the [`{ggthemeassist}`](https://github.com/calligross/ggthemeassist) add-in # More themes * The [`{hrbrthemes}`](https://github.com/hrbrmstr/hrbrthemes) are nice * Consider [building your own theme!](https://bookdown.org/rdpeng/RProgDA/building-a-new-theme.html) * Or Google around . . . * Set the theme globally + One of the first lines in your .qmd file (after you load packages) could be: `theme_set(theme_minimal())` ## Get a little fancy * You can use `geom_point()` for more than one layer * You can also use a different data source on a layer * Use these two properties to highlight points + How about penguins from Torgersen Island? ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "black") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="4"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "black") + geom_point(data = dplyr::filter(penguins, island == "Torgersen"), color = "magenta") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="5"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "black") + geom_point(data = dplyr::filter(penguins, island == "Torgersen"), color = "magenta") + geom_smooth(se = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="6"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "black") + geom_point(data = dplyr::filter(penguins, island == "Torgersen"), color = "magenta") + geom_smooth(se = FALSE) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Another option `{gghighlight}` varying flexibility ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point(color = "magenta") + gghighlight::gghighlight(island == "Torgersen") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Line plots When should you use line plots instead of smooths? . . . * *Usually when time is involved* . . . What are some good candidate data for line plots? . . . * *Oserved versus model-implied (estimated)* ## `geom_line()` Classic time series example `economics` data from `{ggplot2}` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} economics ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 574 × 6 date pce pop psavert uempmed unemploy 1 1967-07-01 507. 198712 12.6 4.5 2944 2 1967-08-01 510. 198911 12.6 4.7 2945 3 1967-09-01 516. 199113 11.9 4.6 2958 4 1967-10-01 512. 199311 12.9 4.9 3143 5 1967-11-01 517. 199498 12.8 4.7 3066 6 1967-12-01 525. 199657 11.8 4.8 3018 7 1968-01-01 531. 199808 11.7 5.1 2878 8 1968-02-01 534. 199920 12.3 4.5 3001 9 1968-03-01 544. 200056 11.7 4.1 2877 10 1968-04-01 544 200208 12.3 4.6 2709 # ℹ 564 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Let's try it How do you think we'd fit a line plot to these data, showing unemployment ("_unemploy_") over time? . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Layers What happens when we layer geom_line and geom_point? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + geom_point() ``` ::: [try it!]{style="color:#D55E00;"} . . . Not the best instance of this It would work better on a plot with fewer time points, but you get the idea # Labels `labs()` ## Axis Labels ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5|6"} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Date", y = "Unemployment") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Title ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|7"} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Date", y = "Unemployment", title = "Unemployment Over Time") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Subtitle ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|8"} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Date", y = "Unemployment", title = "Unemployment Over Time", subtitle = "This is the subtitle") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Caption ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|9"} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Date", y = "Unemployment", title = "Unemployment Over Time", subtitle = "This is the subtitle", caption = "Created by Joe Nese") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Tag ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|10"} economics %>% ggplot(aes(date, unemploy)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Date", y = "Unemployment", title = "Unemployment Over Time", subtitle = "This is the subtitle", caption = "Created by Joe Nese", tag = "(A)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Legend (one way) ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2,7"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, color = species)) + # 'color = ' geom_point() + theme_minimal() + labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", color = "Species!") # 'color = ' ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/axes-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Facets ## Faceting * One of the most powerful features of `{ggplot2}` * Produce *n* plots by a specific variable * `facet_wrap()` + wrap a sequence of panels into two dimensions + based on variables(s) ## Faceting ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(~species) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/facet-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Careful about the `~` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'species' not found ``` ::: ::: ## Faceting two variables (like a matrix) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(species ~ year) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Alternative specification - `vars()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(vars(species)) ``` :::
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(vars(species, year)) ``` ::: # Heatmaps > A heatmap is a literal way of visualizing a table of numbers, where you substitute the numbers with colored cells.
- Nathan Yau * Useful for finding highs and lows - and sometimes patterns * They don't always work well ## Example with correlations ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corr <- cor(mtcars) pc <- corr %>% as.data.frame() %>% mutate(row = rownames(.)) %>% pivot_longer( cols = -row, names_to = "col", values_to = "cor" ) head(pc) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 row col cor 1 mpg mpg 1 2 mpg cyl -0.852 3 mpg disp -0.848 4 mpg hp -0.776 5 mpg drat 0.681 6 mpg wt -0.868 ``` ::: ::: ## Heatmap ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pc %>% ggplot(aes(row, col, fill = cor)) + geom_tile() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Viridis ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} pc %>% ggplot(aes(row, col, fill = cor)) + geom_tile() + scale_fill_viridis_c() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Categorical Data ## Data `{fivethirtyeight}` package dataset is `college_grad_students` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 16)) #install.packages("fivethirtyeight") library(fivethirtyeight) # View(college_grad_students) grad <- college_grad_students # simpler reference grad ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 173 × 22 major_code major major_category grad_total grad_sample_size grad_employed 1 5601 Construc… Industrial Ar… 9173 200 7098 2 6004 Commerci… Arts 53864 882 40492 3 6211 Hospital… Business 24417 437 18368 4 2201 Cosmetol… Industrial Ar… 5411 72 3590 5 2001 Communic… Computers & M… 9109 171 7512 6 3201 Court Re… Law & Public … 1542 22 1008 7 6206 Marketin… Business 190996 3738 151570 8 1101 Agricult… Agriculture &… 17488 386 13104 9 2101 Computer… Computers & M… 5611 98 4716 10 1904 Advertis… Communication… 33928 688 28517 # ℹ 163 more rows # ℹ 16 more variables: grad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # grad_unemployed , grad_unemployment_rate , grad_p25th , # grad_median , grad_p75th , nongrad_total , # nongrad_employed , nongrad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # nongrad_unemployed , nongrad_unemployment_rate , # nongrad_p25th , nongrad_median , nongrad_p75th , … ``` ::: ::: ## Histogram Histogram of "grad_total" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grad %>% ggplot(aes(x = grad_total)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Transparency - `alpha` Add some transparency – perhaps this looks nicer ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} grad %>% ggplot(aes(x = grad_total)) + geom_histogram(alpha = 0.7) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## `color` vs. `fill` **In general** * `color` defines the color a geom is *outlined* * `fill` defines the color a geom is *filled* ## `color` vs. `fill` For example: * `geom_point()` default has only has a color and **NO** fill because they're just points * Point shapes 21–24 include both a color and a fill ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## How would we change the color of this plot? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grad %>% ggplot(aes(x = grad_total)) + geom_histogram(alpha = 0.7) ``` ::: ## How would we change the color of this plot? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grad %>% ggplot(aes(x = grad_total)) + geom_histogram(alpha = 0.7, color = "magenta") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## How would we change the ~~color~~ fill of this plot? ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} grad %>% ggplot(aes(x = grad_total)) + geom_histogram(alpha = 0.7, fill = "magenta") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Color by variable What if we wanted different colors by a variable -- *species* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_histogram(aes(fill = species), alpha = 0.7) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Density plot Alternative representation of distribution * Think of it as a smoothed histogram (uses kernel smoothing) * The depiction of the distribution is **NOT** determined by the number of the bins you use, as are histograms ## Density plot `geom_density()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_density() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Density plot Now let’s fill by *species* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_density(aes(fill = species), alpha = 0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Possible alternative? `facet_wrap` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g)) + geom_density(alpha = 0.2) + facet_wrap(~species) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Even better density ridges `{ggridges}` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggridges) penguins %>% ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = species)) + geom_density_ridges() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## `fill` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm , species)) + geom_density_ridges(aes(fill = factor(year))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-41-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Add transparency for clarity ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm , species)) + geom_density_ridges(aes(fill = factor(year)), alpha = 0.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-42-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Viridis * easier to read by those with colorblindness * prints well in gray scale ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm , species)) + geom_density_ridges(aes(fill = factor(year)), alpha = 0.5) + scale_fill_viridis_d() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-43-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Same fill function, different "`option`" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} penguins %>% ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm , species)) + geom_density_ridges(aes(fill = factor(year)), alpha = 0.7) + scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-44-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Candy rankings `{fivethirtyeight}` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} candy <- candy_rankings %>% pivot_longer( cols = chocolate:pluribus, names_to = "type", values_to = "foo") %>% filter(foo) %>% select(-foo) candy ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 197 × 5 competitorname sugarpercent pricepercent winpercent type 1 100 Grand 0.732 0.860 67.0 chocolate 2 100 Grand 0.732 0.860 67.0 caramel 3 100 Grand 0.732 0.860 67.0 crispedricewafer 4 100 Grand 0.732 0.860 67.0 bar 5 3 Musketeers 0.604 0.511 67.6 chocolate 6 3 Musketeers 0.604 0.511 67.6 nougat 7 3 Musketeers 0.604 0.511 67.6 bar 8 Air Heads 0.906 0.511 52.3 fruity 9 Almond Joy 0.465 0.767 50.3 chocolate 10 Almond Joy 0.465 0.767 50.3 peanutyalmondy # ℹ 187 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Boxplot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% ggplot(aes(type, sugarpercent)) + geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-46-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Violin plots ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% ggplot(aes(type, sugarpercent)) + geom_violin() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-47-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Bar Charts ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(mpg) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 11 manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto(l5) f 18 29 p compa… 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manual(m5) f 21 29 p compa… 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manual(m6) f 20 31 p compa… 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto(av) f 21 30 p compa… 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto(l5) f 16 26 p compa… 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manual(m5) f 18 26 p compa… ``` ::: ::: ## Bar/Col Charts {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **`geom_bar()`** * expects *x* **OR** *y* * counts rows * if you want to count the number of cases at each *x* or *y* position * makes the height of the bar proportional to the number of cases in each group * uses `stat_count()` by default ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **`geom_col()`** * expects *x* **AND** *y* * expects numbers in your data * if you want the heights of the bars to represent values in the data * leaves the data as is

* uses `stat_identity()` by default ::: :::: ## `geom_bar()` *mpg* data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + # one variable in the `aes()` geom_bar() # counts the rows per class ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-49-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## *summarized_mpg* data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg <- mpg %>% group_by(class) %>% count() head(summarized_mpg) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 # Groups: class [6] class n 1 2seater 5 2 compact 47 3 midsize 41 4 minivan 11 5 pickup 33 6 subcompact 35 ``` ::: ::: ## `geom_col()` *summarized_mpg* data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class, n)) + # two variables in the `aes()` geom_col() # data has the rows per class in "n" ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-51-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} `geom_bar()` default ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-52-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="60%" .fragment} `geom_bar(stat = "identity")` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class, n)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-53-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## :::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} `geom_bar()` default ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-54-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="60%" .fragment} `geom_col()` default ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class, n)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-55-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## :::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} `geom_bar()` default ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-56-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="60%" .fragment} `geom_bar()` uh-oh ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-57-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## What happened? Let's look at our data again :::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 7 × 2 # Groups: class [7] class n 1 2seater 5 2 compact 47 3 midsize 41 4 minivan 11 5 pickup 33 6 subcompact 35 7 suv 62 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summarized_mpg %>% ggplot(aes(class)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-59-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## More bar plot options {.smaller} ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} eclsk <- haven::read_sav(here::here("data", "ecls-k_samp.sav")) %>% rio::characterize() %>% janitor::clean_names() ecls_smry <- eclsk %>% group_by(k_type, ethnic) %>% summarize(t1r_mean = mean(t1rscale)) ecls_smry ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 16 × 3 # Groups: k_type [2] k_type ethnic t1r_mean 1 full-day AMERICAN INDIAN OR ALASKA NATIVE 17.5 2 full-day ASIAN 31.8 3 full-day BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN, NON-HISPANIC 21.1 4 full-day HISPANIC, RACE NOT SPECIFIED 20.3 5 full-day HISPANIC, RACE SPECIFIED 22.3 6 full-day MORE THAN ONE RACE, NON HISPANIC 20.8 7 full-day NATIVE HAWAIIAN, OTHER PACIFIC ISLANDER 23.2 8 full-day WHITE, NON-HISPANIC 25.5 9 half-day AMERICAN INDIAN OR ALASKA NATIVE 30.0 10 half-day ASIAN 25.1 11 half-day BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN, NON-HISPANIC 18.6 12 half-day HISPANIC, RACE NOT SPECIFIED 18.7 13 half-day HISPANIC, RACE SPECIFIED 20.0 14 half-day MORE THAN ONE RACE, NON HISPANIC 20.3 15 half-day NATIVE HAWAIIAN, OTHER PACIFIC ISLANDER 19.7 16 half-day WHITE, NON-HISPANIC 23.7 ``` ::: ::: ## Stacked bar plot Look for effects in "ethnicity" by "k_type" (full/half day K) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(ethnic, t1r_mean)) + geom_col(aes(fill = k_type)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-61-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Grouped bar plot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(ethnic, t1r_mean)) + geom_col(aes(fill = k_type), position = "dodge") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-62-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Rotating Labels I have to look [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1330989/rotating-and-spacing-axis-labels-in-ggplot2) up *every* time ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(ethnic, t1r_mean)) + geom_col(aes(fill = k_type), position = "dodge") + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-63-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Flip the coordinates `coord_flip()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(ethnic, t1r_mean)) + geom_col(aes(fill = k_type), position = "dodge") + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-64-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Alternatively `facet_wrap()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(k_type, t1r_mean)) + geom_col(alpha = 0.8) + facet_wrap(~ethnic) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-65-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Sometimes some redundancy works well ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ecls_smry %>% ggplot(aes(k_type, t1r_mean, fill = k_type)) + geom_col(alpha = 0.8) + facet_wrap(~ethnic) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w3_ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-66-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## `geom_*()` Review {.smaller} * `geom_point()` * `geom_smooth()` * `geom_line()` * `geom_tile()` * `geom_histogram()` * `geom_density()` * `ggridges::geom_density_ridges()` * `geom_boxplot()` * `geom_violin()` * `geom_bar()` * `geom_col()` ## Challenge {.smaller} * Start a new `R` project * Create a new script, save it as "practice-plots.R" * Load the `{tidyverse}` * Print the **msleep** dataset to see it's structure (it's from `{ggplot2}`) For each of the following, produce a separate plot 1. Plot the relation between "sleep_total" and "brainwt" (with "brainwt" as the DV) - scatter plot 2. Overlay a smooth on the previous plot 3. Color the points by "vore", but fit a single smooth 4. Fit separate smooths by "vore", but with all points being gray 5. Omit the standard error of the smooths 6. Use `ylim()` as an additional layer to restrict the *y*-axis to range from 0 to 5 # Next time ## Before next class {.smaller} * Reading + [R4DS(2e) 4](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-transform) * Supplemental Learning + [Codecademy: Modifying Data Frames](https://www.codecademy.com/courses/learn-r/lessons/r-data-frames-modifying) + [Codecademy: Aggregates in R](https://www.codecademy.com/courses/learn-r/lessons/r-aggregates/exercises/column-statistics) * Homework + **Homework 2** + **Homework 3**
